comments.commentBody: Hangwringing editorials by the New York Times will not affect the Republican stance toward minorities including Hispanics. Even losing seats will not affect the Republican stance. The only serious change will come when electoral losses significantly alter public policies such as tax rates and priorities, worker safety and benefits, the demise of Citizens United,elimination of the fraud of corporations as persons, and constraints on money in politics. Start removing privileges and special status and the Republicans will come to Jesus in a real hurry. Embarrassment means nothing, privilege means everything. I am a Republican and I understand the internal dynamics of the party.

In 1924 the Klu Klux Klan infiltrated and took over the Democratic Party National Convention, denying nomination to then New York Governor Al Smith because he was a Roman Catholic. Placed in nomination in 1924 by FDR, Smith had to wait another four years to gain the nomination only to lose to Herbert Hoover, setting up his fortunate succession by FDR himself first as governor, then as presidential nominee and ultimately as a providential president.

The Cleveland convention looks like the KKK is back in full command and has suborned or, worse, been resurrected in the Former Republican Party, a party born not as an anti-slavery party but out of the Free Soil Movement of the 1850s.

It turns out the Former Republican Party's "Big Tent" is only for angry white people: No one else need apply.

Appalling. Absolutely appalling.

Republicans, come ride the PATH and the New York City subways with me and see the new America. It does not look like you, it is not like you, it is not you. It does not like you and you are doomed by its intense dislike of what you have become, the party of race hatred, conformed ignorance and desperately lost and left behind people.

In the last months of his life, James Baldwin said that he represented a very complex country which insists on being simple-minded. He said simplicity and sincerity are taken to be great American virtues, even if you don’t know what you’re talking about. His observation has been demonstrated beyond cavil in Cleveland this week.

From what I have seen and read about this convention, I am left with a question that I just can't get out of my head - what thinking person would get on board with this bubbling vat of hate? There is no policy, there is no realistic plan and there isn't even the pretense to offer a plan or policy. Hate Democrats, imprison Hillary, deport immigrants, register and monitor Muslims - just take every grievance and frustration you have and blame it all on "one of those people". Don't think, don't be circumspect about your own role in your life - they are the enemy, the devil, so hate "them". Who can think this is good for our nation? And it is not just Trump. He just happens to fit the bill quite well to lead this apocalyptic bunch.

So far, the Republicans have done fairly well by peddling fear and hate to the American people. The domestic dangers, the Trump Republicans tell us, are many: Mexicans. Muslims, blacks, homosexuals, and those old favorites, free-loading poor people.

The bet the Republicans are making is simple. The fear mongering, they believe, will bring out the vote of sufficient numbers of conservative-leaning white Americans to outweigh the votes of white liberals and people of color, with the latter group reduced by aggressive voter suppression efforts.

In the long run, the tactics of today will doom the Republican Party. Unfortunately, those tactics could win in November 2016, unless Democrats show much more fight and grit.

The GOP standard bearer referred to my wife and her family as criminals, rapists and drug dealers.  She, and her siblings, immigrated to the US 35 years ago, are naturalized citizens, are educated, professionals, and employers.  But because they are from South America the GOP has declared them persons non grata.  While Trump's surrogates argue that Trump meant only illegal immigrants, Trump has only referred to immigrants.  And that means he and his party are simply racists.

When that crowd shouted 'Lock her up', a chill went through me, and I wonder if Hillary Clinton, for the first time, feared for her own safety. The spectacle fills me with sadness, first for how low this democracy has descended, with the acquiescence, even encouragement, of people who should know better. And second, that no matter what happens to the Trump campaign, almost half of the voting population of the country will vote for him, a man who at every turn disrespects the very office he is running for.

The idea of an engagement tour is in itself racist. It assumes that Latinos, as a group. are naive and have short attention spans. The idea is based upon the belief that a whole sub-set of the population can be insulted and denigrated, then, offered platitudes and images of Mr. Trump happily eating Tacos, they will like naive, happy children come around to love him. What Trump & Co do not understand is that Latinos (as well as African-Americans, Asian-Americans, Native Americans, Muslims and others) are thinking, intelligent adults who listen, understand, and remember what was said and how they have been treated.
"Diversity" defined in the dictionary of Trumpism: white people of many different sizes and weights.

I would love to see a column on the irony of the Republicans blaming all their problems and their economic state on "others". Are these not the same people who blame the poor and unemployed for their own problems and say they need to just solve their personal problems to get ahead? Can't everyone see the hypocrisy in all of this blame game? I mean, how can you miss it!
"Surreal" would be one way to put it. I think "macabre" is better. I've been to two world fairs and a sheep-shearing contest, and I don't think I've witnessed anything like this spectacle.

While the number of Latinos supporting Donald Trump is small, this group does exist. The concerns that I have come to understand have centered around the undocumented status of other Latinos who have entered the United States. "They should enter legally like we did" seems to be the prevailing sentiment. However, the fact remains, while people can see in your face that you are Latino, your immigrant status is less apparent. If Donald Trump gets elected, the hate and vitriol he and his supporters have spewed so far will not stop to check immigrant status or citizenship before they make their views known, on the street, in shops, on the job, in the news, and everywhere else. For those who are not convinced, one name comes to mind, Gonzalo Curiel. Being born in Indiana didn't stop Trump for expressing his Racism toward this federal judge. Donald Trump has accused Hillary Clinton of "playing the woman card," and others of "playing the race." Donald Trump is playing the Racist Card. He is openly, unabashedly, joyfully, and wholeheartedly playing the Racist Card. His message is clear. He is a Racist according to Paul Ryan and many other Republicans. But he gets votes from the Republican base. Why? It's self-evident. The Republican base is Racist. It's in the rhetoric, the policies, the advertisements (Willie Horton). Donald Trump has seen it clearly and he embraced the Racism of the Republican base. Electing Trump is make America hate, even more.
